bioghist.p: Edward Sculley Bradley (1919-1967) was a professor of English and American Literature and a vice-provost at the University of Pennsylvania.

scopecontent.p: The collection includes documentation related to various censorship cases. Materials include correspondence with Arthur Farmer of Stern and Reubens, Attorneys, regarding the defense of Philadelphia booksellers for the sale of God's Little Acre by Erskine Caldwell, Sanctuary and Wild Palms by William Faulkner, and Studs Lonigan by James T. Farrell (1948-1950); correspondence with Manuel Lee Robbins of Stern and Reubens with Bradley's comments and testimony in the book trail of Find Me a River by Robert Lowry and Duke by Hal Ellson (1950-1953); correspondence with Robbins with Bradley's comments and testimony in the book trail of Find Me In Fire by Robert Lowry (1953-1954); correspondence with Robbins with Bradley's comments and testimony in the book trail of Down All Your Streets by Leonard Bishop (1953-1954); newspaper clippings and magazine articles, correspondence and Bradley's notes related to the book trials of Tropic of Cancer by Henry Miller (1962) and the conviction of Eros magazine publisher Ralph Ginzberg (1966); and a 1948 Judge Bok decision on the Philadelphia booksellers case.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
